original: tasya mānasottarasya madhye triṣahasrayojanapramāṇo nyagrodhataruḥ / tasmin brahmā saparivāro nivasati /
analyzed: tasya mānasottarasya madhye tri sahasra yojana pramāṇaḥ nyagrodha taruḥ tasmin brahmā sa parivāraḥ nivasati
translated: In the middle of that Manosottara, there is a banyan tree 3,000 yojanas in size. Brahma resides there with his retinue.

analyzed: tasya uttareṇa hari ardha tanoḥ śambhoḥ niketanam
translated: To the north of that, is the abode of Shambhu, whose body is half-lion.

analyzed: vasati asmin hari haraḥ pūjyamānaḥ sura asuraiḥ
translated: Harihara resides in this, worshipped by gods and demons.

original: puṣkarād dviguṇo bāhye svādūdaḥ sāgaro mahān /🔽tadbāhye daśakoṭyāsti yojanānāṃ hiraṇyabhūḥ // //
analyzed: puṣkarāt dviguṇaḥ bāhye svādu udaḥ sāgaraḥ mahān  tad bāhye daśa koṭyā asti yojanānām hiraṇyabhūḥ
translated: Outside that, twice the size of Pushkara, is the great ocean of sweet water.🔽Outside that, there is the golden earth, ten million yojanas in size.

analyzed: svādu abdheḥ tu bahis hiraṇya dharaṇiḥ koṭyā daśa āsyā bahi
translated: Outside the ocean of sweet water, the golden earth is ten million yojanas in size.

original: rlokālokagiristu merusadṛśaścotsedhavistārataḥ /🔽p / nirjīvaḥ khalu bāhyato'sya tu tamaḥ ṣaṭtriṃśatā koṭibhi
analyzed: rlokāloka giriḥ tu meru sadṛśaḥ ca utsedha vistārataḥ  nirjīvaḥ khalu bāhyatas sya tu tamaḥ
translated: Outside that, is the Lokāloka mountain, equal to Meru in height and width.🔽It is indeed lifeless on the outside, but on the inside, it is darkness for thirty-six million yojanas.

original: rbāhye cāṇḍakaṭāhataḥ sa ca ghanaḥ ṣaṭkoṭigavyūtibhiḥ // //
analyzed: rbāhye ca aṇḍa kaṭāhataḥ sa ca ghanaḥ ṣaṣ koṭi gavyūtibhiḥ
translated: And outside the shell of the universe, it is solid for six million yojanas.

original: alamatiprasaṅgena / atha bhuvarlokādayaḥ kathyante / tad yathā 🔽bhūmerūrdhvaṃ yojanānāṃ lakṣe sūryagatiḥ smṛtā /
analyzed: alam atiprasaṅgena atha bhuvarloka ādayaḥ kathyante tat yathā  bhūmeḥ ūrdhvam yojanānām lakṣe sūrya gatiḥ smṛtā
translated: Enough of this digression. Now the Bhuvarloka and others are described. As follows:🔽The path of the sun is said to be one lakh yojanas above the earth.

analyzed: yojanaiḥ nava sāhasraiḥ viṣkambha urka rathasya tu
translated: The width of the chariot of the sun is nine thousand yojanas.

analyzed: tad prabhā maṇḍalam tasmāt triguṇam hi pramāṇataḥ
translated: The disc of its light is three times larger than that.

analyzed: sūrya lokaḥ tu vijñeyaḥ vimāna śata saṅkulaḥ
translated: The world of the sun should be known to be crowded with hundreds of palaces.

analyzed: udyānaiḥ ramyaiḥ śobhitaḥ sa jalāśayaiḥ
translated: It is adorned with beautiful gardens, assembly halls and water reservoirs.

original: sūryāllakṣe sthitaścandrastasmānnakṣatramaṇḍalam // //🔽tasmād dvilakṣe tu budho dvilakṣe'smācca bhārgavaḥ /
analyzed: sūryāt lakṣe sthitaḥ candraḥ tasmāt nakṣatra maṇḍalam  tasmāt dvi lakṣe tu budhaḥ dvi lakṣe ismāt ca bhārgavaḥ
translated: The moon is situated at a distance of one lakh from the sun. Beyond that is the sphere of the stars.🔽At a distance of two lakh from that is Mercury. At a distance of two lakh from that is Venus.

analyzed: dvi lakṣe bhārgavāt bhaumaḥ tadvat bhaumāt bṛhaspatiḥ  /
translated: At a distance of two lakh from Venus is Mars. At a distance of two lakh from Mars is Jupiter.

analyzed: yojanānām dvi lakṣe tu guroḥ sauriḥ vyavasthitaḥ
translated: At a distance of two lakh yojanas from Jupiter, Saturn is situated.

analyzed: rathaḥ tri cakraḥ somasya kunda gaurāḥ ca vājinaḥ
translated: The chariot of the moon has three wheels and is drawn by horses white like jasmine.

original: daśa te ca vahantyenaṃ somalokastu sa smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: daśa te ca vahanti enam soma lokaḥ tu sa smṛtaḥ
translated: Those ten draw it. That is known as the world of Soma.

original: raktāṣṭāśvo budhasyāpi ratho lokaḥ sa tasya hi // //🔽kusumbhasadṛśāṣṭāśvaḥ śukrasyāpi ratho mahān /
analyzed: rakta aṣṭa aśvaḥ budhasya api rathaḥ lokaḥ sa tasya hi  kusumbha sadṛśa aṣṭa aśvaḥ śukrasya api rathaḥ mahān
translated: The chariot of Mercury also has eight red horses. That is his world.🔽The great chariot of Venus has eight horses resembling safflower.

original: padmarāgāruṇāṣṭāśvo haimo bhaumasya vai rathaḥ // //🔽rathastu pāṇḍarāṣṭāśvo haimaḥ khyāto bṛhaspateḥ /
analyzed: padmarāga aruṇa aṣṭa aśvaḥ haimaḥ bhaumasya vai rathaḥ  rathaḥ tu pāṇḍara aṣṭa aśvaḥ haimaḥ khyātaḥ bṛhaspateḥ
translated: The golden chariot of Mars has eight horses red like rubies.🔽The chariot of Jupiter is known to have eight white horses and is golden.

analyzed: rathaḥ tu śabala aṣṭa aśvaḥ śaneḥ api hiraṇmayaḥ
translated: The chariot of Saturn also has eight variegated horses and is made of gold.

analyzed: dhūmaraḥ tu rathaḥ rāhoḥ nīla aṣṭa aśvaiḥ alaṅkṛtaḥ
translated: The chariot of Rahu is smoky, adorned with eight blue horses.

original: aṣṭau dhūmrāruṇāḥ ketoraśvā yuktā rathe smṛtāḥ // //
analyzed: aṣṭau dhūmra aruṇāḥ ketoḥ aśvāḥ yuktāḥ rathe smṛtāḥ
translated: Eight smoky-red horses are remembered as yoked to the chariot of Ketu.

analyzed: tayoḥ api sthitiḥ khyātā hi adhastāt soma sūryayoḥ
translated: The position of both of them is known below the moon and the sun.

original: eteṣāṃ tu pṛthag lokāsta eva parikīrtitāḥ // //
analyzed: eteṣām tu pṛthak lokāḥ te eva parikīrtitāḥ
translated: The separate worlds of these are indeed declared.

original: śanerupari lakṣe tu saptarṣīṇāṃ tu maṇḍalam /
analyzed: śaneḥ upari lakṣe tu saptarṣīṇām tu maṇḍalam
translated: Above Śani, at a distance of one lakh, is the sphere of the Seven Sages.

original: teṣāmupari lakṣe tu medhībhūte dhruvaḥ sthitaḥ // //
analyzed: teṣām upari lakṣe tu medhībhūte dhruvaḥ sthitaḥ  /
translated: Above them, at a distance of one lakh, Dhruva is situated, the pivot of the universe.

original: grahanakṣatratārāṇāṃ prerako dhruva īritaḥ /🔽bhūmerūrdhvaṃ bhuvarlokastvā nakṣatrapathāt smṛtaḥ // //🔽p / tadūrdhvamā dhruvapathāt svarlokaḥ svarga ucyate /
analyzed: graha nakṣatra tārāṇām prerakaḥ dhruvaḥ īritaḥ  bhūmeḥ ūrdhvam bhuvarlokaḥ tvā nakṣatra pathāt smṛtaḥ  tad ūrdhvam ā dhruva pathāt svar lokaḥ svargaḥ ucyate
translated: Dhruva is said to be the impeller of the planets, stars and constellations.🔽Above the earth is the Bhuvarloka, known as the path of the stars.🔽Above that, at a distance of one lakh from the path of Dhruva, is the Svarloka, called heaven.

original: tatrāmarāvatī nāma śakrasya tu purī śubhā // //
analyzed: tatra amarāvatī nāma śakrasya tu purī śubhā  /
translated: There is the auspicious city of Indra named Amaravati.

analyzed: devarṣīṇām vimānāni tatra santi sahasraśas
translated: There are thousands of celestial vehicles of the celestial sages.

original: ādityānāṃ ca rudrāṇāṃ vasūnāmaśvinorapi // //🔽marutāmapi sādhyānāṃ purāṇi bhuvanāni ca /
analyzed: ādityānām ca rudrāṇām vasūnām aśvinoḥ api  marutām api sādhyānām purāṇi bhuvanāni ca
translated: And of the Adityas, Rudras, Vasus, Ashvins,🔽Maruts and Sadhyas, there are cities and worlds.

analyzed: sva dikṣu lokapālānām rājarṣīṇām ca mukhyaśas
translated: In their respective directions are the cities of the Lokapalas and the chief royal sages.

analyzed: gandharvāṇām pitṝṇām ca vimānāni sahasraśas
translated: The palaces of the Gandharvas and the Pitris are in thousands.

original: anyeṣāṃ ca svargajitāmāvāsaḥ svari taḥ / tismṛtaḥ // //
analyzed: anyeṣām ca svarga jitām āvāsaḥ svari taḥ
translated: And the abode of others who have conquered heaven is known as Svarga.

analyzed: te sva puṇya anurūpān tu bhogān tatra eva bhuñjate
translated: They enjoy there the pleasures befitting their own merits.

original: śiṃśumāro dhruvasyāpi syādādhāro dhruvopari // //🔽dhruvāt koṭyā maharloko vaimānikasurairvṛtaḥ /
analyzed: śiṃśumāraḥ dhruvasya api syāt ādhāraḥ dhruva upari  dhruvāt koṭyā mahar lokaḥ vaimānika suraiḥ vṛtaḥ
translated: The porpoise is also the support of Dhruva, and Dhruva is above it.🔽Beyond Dhruva, a million leagues above, is the world of Mahar, surrounded by the gods who travel in aerial cars.

analyzed: koṭi dvaye mahar lokāt ūrdhvam lokaḥ janaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: Two million leagues above the world of Mahar, the world of Jana is said to be.

original: tatra siddhā vidhāneṣu mānasā brahmaṇaḥ sutāḥ /
analyzed: tatra siddhāḥ vidhāneṣu mānasāḥ brahmaṇaḥ sutāḥ
translated: There the Siddhas, the mental sons of Brahma, who are created by the ordinance,

analyzed: nivasanti mahātmānaḥ yoga aiśvarya upabṛṃhitāḥ
translated: dwell, those high-souled ones, endowed with the prosperity of Yoga.

analyzed: ā brahma pralayāt iti yāvat
translated: Up to the dissolution of Brahma.

analyzed: koṭi traye janāt ūrdhvam tapolokaḥ pratiṣṭhitaḥ
translated: Beyond Jana, three million leagues above, the world of Tapas is established.

original: vairājā nāma ye devāstapoloke vasanti te // //
analyzed: vairājāḥ nāma ye devāḥ tapaḥ loke vasanti te  /
translated: The gods named Vairajas dwell in the world of Tapas.

analyzed: ā brahmapralayāt te pi vasanti
translated: They also dwell up to the dissolution of Brahma.

analyzed: tapolokāt tu ṣaṣ koṭyām ūrdhvam satyam pratiṣṭhitam
translated: But beyond the world of Tapas, six million leagues above, the world of Satya is established.

analyzed: brahma lokaḥ tu sa jñeyaḥ ābrahma pralayā sthitiḥ
translated: That should be known as the world of Brahma, and it exists up to the dissolution of Brahma.

analyzed: prajānām patayaḥ ca eva dakṣa bhṛgu ādayaḥ malāḥ
translated: And the lords of creatures, Daksha, Bhrigu and others, who are pure,

analyzed: brahma loka jitaḥ anye ca yatayaḥ brahma vādinaḥ
translated: And other ascetics who have conquered the world of Brahman and are expounders of Brahman.

original: yatra yad brahmasadanaṃ na tad varṇayituṃ kṣamam /
analyzed: yatra yat brahma sadanam na tat varṇayitum kṣamam
translated: Where the abode of Brahman cannot be described.

analyzed: satyalokāt tatas kiñcid ūrdhvam viṣṇu puram mahat
translated: Slightly above the world of truth, there is the great city of Vishnu.

analyzed: tejaḥ mayam aparyantam tat na varṇayitum kṣamam
translated: It is full of light and infinite, and cannot be described.

analyzed: brāhme brahmā sadā eva āste pūjyamānaḥ sura ādibhiḥ
translated: In the world of Brahman, Brahman always resides, worshipped by the gods and others.

analyzed: sva loke bhagavān viṣṇuḥ āste nanta āsane vibhuḥ
translated: In his own world, the Lord Vishnu resides on an endless throne, the all-pervading one.

analyzed: yogibhiḥ kumuda ādyaiḥ ca viṣvaksena ādibhiḥ gaṇaiḥ
translated: By the yogis Kumuda and others, and by the groups led by Visvaksena,

analyzed: cakra ādyaiḥ ca āyudhaiḥ sarvaiḥ mūrtimadbhiḥ upasthitaḥ
translated: And by all the weapons like the discus, which have assumed forms and are present.

analyzed: yojanānām tathā koṭyām viṣṇu lokāt atha upari
translated: And above the world of Vishnu, which is a crore of yojanas,

analyzed: rudra lokaḥ sthitaḥ tasya prabhāvaḥ noditum kṣamaḥ
translated: The world of Rudra is situated. Its power cannot be described.

analyzed: jyotiḥ prākāra saṃvītaḥ sūrya koṭi sama prabhaḥ
translated: It is surrounded by a wall of light, and has the radiance of a crore of suns.

analyzed: tatra divya vapūḥ devaḥ trinetraḥ candraśekharaḥ
translated: There, the god with a divine form, having three eyes and the moon on his head,

analyzed: skanda nandi gaṇa īśaiḥ ca gaṇaiḥ divya vapuḥ dharaiḥ
translated: Is worshipped by Skanda, Nandi, Ganesha and other groups, who have divine forms,

analyzed: upāsyamānaḥ sārūpya muktaiḥ īśa arcane rataiḥ
translated: And by those liberated through identity with him, who are engaged in worshipping the Lord.

analyzed: āste divya vimāneṣu śaśvat devyā saha umayā
translated: resides in divine aerial cars, always with the goddess Uma.

original: alaṃ varṇanayā / bhūrādisatyānteṣu pṛthak pṛthag rudrāstadadhipatayaḥ sapta /
analyzed: alam varṇanayā bhūḥ ādi satya anteṣu pṛthak pṛthak rudrāḥ tad adhipatayaḥ sapta
translated: Enough of description. In the worlds beginning with Bhu and ending with Satya, there are seven Rudras, the lords of each world, separately.

analyzed: yathā mañjaryām
translated: As stated in the Manjari Tantra:

original: bhūmau subhadro divi vāyuvegaḥ svarge mahāvīryaparākramākhyaḥ /
analyzed: bhūmau subhadraḥ divi vāyu vegaḥ svarge mahā vīrya parākrama ākhyaḥ
translated: On the earth, Subhadra; in the sky, Vayuvega; in heaven, Mahavirya and Paraakrama;

original: rudro mahaḥstho vikaṭaḥ parastāt khyāto mahākālakavaidyutau ca //
analyzed: rudraḥ mahaḥsthaḥ vikaṭaḥ parastāt khyātaḥ mahākālaka vaidyutau ca
translated: The Rudra in the Mahas, Vikata; beyond that, known as Mahaakala and Kaividyuta.

analyzed: satya loka īśvaraḥ śvetaḥ tatas brahmā tatas hariḥ
translated: The lord of the Satyaloka is Shveta; beyond that, Brahma; beyond that, Hari.

analyzed: rudraḥ svayam sva loka īśaḥ brahmāṇḍa antar iti īritaḥ
translated: Rudra himself is the lord of his own world, described as within the Cosmic Egg.

original: atha brahmāṇḍād bāhyato daśadikṣu pratidiśaṃ daśa daśa rudrapurāṇi teṣāṃ nāmadheyāni kapālīśādiśatarudrāṇāṃ saṃjñāvedyāni / atra pauṣkare
analyzed: atha brahmāṇḍāt bāhyatas daśa dikṣu pratidiśam daśa daśa rudra purāṇi teṣām nāmadheyāni kapāli īśa ādi śata rudrāṇām saṃjñā vedyāni atra pauṣkare
translated: Now, outside the Cosmic Egg, in the ten directions, in each direction, there are ten cities of Rudra. The names of those cities are known as the names of the hundred Rudras beginning with Kapalish. Here, in the Pushkara Tantra,

analyzed: lakṣa yojana mānānām tejiṣṭhānām pṛthak pṛthak
translated: they are said to be one lakh yojanas in size, each of them extremely radiant.

analyzed: tatra āste rudra śaktiḥ yā bhadrakālī svakaiḥ gaṇaiḥ
translated: There resides the power of Rudra, Bhadrakali, with her own attendants.

analyzed: evam kālāgni pūrvāṇi bhuvanāni pṛthak pṛthak
translated: Thus, the worlds beginning with Kalaagni, each separately,

analyzed: bhadrakālī pura antāni pṛthvī tattve sthitāni hi
translated: end with the city of Bhadrakali, and are located in the principle of earth.

analyzed: aṣṭottaraśatam bhuvanāni iti yāvat
translated: There are one hundred and eight worlds, that is, up to that point.

analyzed: atas param ca bhuvanāni ap tattva ādi sthitāni hi
translated: And beyond that, the worlds are situated in the principle of water and so on.

original: tāni cātiviśālāni tejiṣṭhāni mahānti ca // //🔽p / svarūpato varṇayituṃ tāni varṣaśatairapi /
analyzed: tāni ca ati viśālāni tejiṣṭhāni mahānti ca  svarūpataḥ varṇayitum tāni varṣa śataiḥ api
translated: And those are extremely vast, most radiant, and great.🔽Even in hundreds of years, it is not possible to describe their nature.

analyzed: na śakyāni yatas grantha gauravāt bhayam asti atas
translated: Because of the fear of the heaviness of the text,

analyzed: samāsena pradarśyante bhuvana adhva prasiddhaye
translated: they are shown concisely for the sake of establishing the path of the worlds.

analyzed: pṛthvī tattvāt atha ap tattvam jñeyam daśaguṇam tatas
translated: Then, the principle of water should be known as ten times greater than the principle of earth.

analyzed: tejaḥ tattvam daśaguṇam tatas vāyuḥ tatas viyat
translated: The principle of fire is ten times greater than that, then air, then space.

original: evamuttarottarapramāṇāni pṛthivyādimāyāntāni tattvāni vidyāt / śuddhavidyeśvarasadāśivatattvāni kramāt sahasraguṇitāni / śaktiśivatattvayoranādyantatvāt parimāṇaṃ nocyate /
analyzed: evam uttarottara pramāṇāni pṛthivī ādi māyā antāni tattvāni vidyāt śuddhavidyeśvara sadāśiva tattvāni kramāt sahasra guṇitāni śakti śiva tattvayoḥ anādi anta tvāt parimāṇam na ucyate
translated: Thus, one should know that the principles from earth up to Maya are progressively larger. The principles of pure knowledge, Isvara, Sada-siva are thousand times greater respectively. translated: Then the Guru, taking his right hand with his own right hand, should enter by the western door, and make him circumambulate the Śambhu pitcher, the Maṇḍala, and Śiva three times, and perform worship. He too, having placed that cupped hand on his own head, having saluted the Guru, should bring it through the Suṣumnā channel in the reverse order of creation and place it in the lotus of his own heart, having flooded it with the nectar at the end of the twelve, having offered oblations with the mantra collection, having invoked and established the Sādhya mantra with its limbs in the lotus posture to the right of the Śiva pitcher and fire, having worshipped it like Śiva, having extracted the mantra from it, the adept should contemplate it in his own body in the order of Śakti and so on and establish it.

translated: Thus, the nine knots should be known to be located at the end of the twelve, the top of the head, the aperture, the forehead, the middle of the eyebrows, the palate, the throat, the heart, the navel, and the genitals. And those are stated for one initiated into Nirvāṇa, and are the same for the adept also. For him also, in brief, the service, the observance of vows, the adoption of a special emblem, the service of pure food, the abandonment of attachments, the lack of interest in punishment and favor, the avoidance of prohibited acts, and the non-abandonment of enjoined duties.

translated: The meaning is that one should avoid them. Moreover, one should avoid a linga that is served by another worshipper, installed by a human, devoid of worship, defiled by the birth of barbarians and untouchables, defective due to being shaken, broken, etc., and having many signs. A single linga, one with a western door, and a self-arisen linga are the best. One installed by gods, sages, or made of stone is medium. One installed by asuras, rakshasas, pisachas, etc. is the lowest. In these lingas, there is no mixing of mantras as they are common to all mantras for all purposes. Therefore, one should deposit one's own mantra in them and worship. In unknown mantra lingas, one should deposit the pranava or the alphabet, bring it to one's heart through pūraka, dissolve it at the end of the twelve (finger spaces) through recaka, deposit one's own mantra according to the prescribed installation, and worship. In the absence of the three types of lingas, the fourth alternative is to resort to a linga that is present by the grace of a guru, oneself, or someone else. After that,

translated: Honored with the kalās beginning with nivṛtti and with Sadya and others,🔽Endowed with all gems, herbs, seeds, clay, fragrances, and flowers,
Adorned with golden fruits and sprouts as mentioned,

analyzed: sa vastra mālā ābharaṇa an āsana ādi krameṇa tu
translated: Along with garments, garlands, ornaments, seats, and so on, in due order,

analyzed: paramīkaraṇa anteṣu ābāhya tu kalāḥ kramāt
translated: Up to the end of the supreme consecration, the kalās are placed externally in order.

analyzed: mūrti aṅgāni abhisampūjya kuṇḍe vahnim ca pūrvavat
translated: Having worshipped the forms and limbs, and in the pit, the fire as before,

analyzed: iṣṭvā pañca āhutīḥ hutvā pṛthvī ādīnām sva nāmabhiḥ
translated: Having worshipped and offered five oblations with the names of earth etc.,

original: kalānāmaṅgamūrtīnāṃ tārahṛnmūlapūrvakam // //🔽samidājyacarūn lājatilān hutvā baliṃ kṣipet /
analyzed: kalānām aṅga mūrtīnām tāra hṛd mūla pūrvakam  samidh ājya carūn lāja tilān hutvā balim kṣipet
translated: Of the parts, the forms of the limbs, preceded by the seed-syllable, the heart, and the root,🔽Having offered sticks, ghee, oblations, parched grain, sesame seeds, one should throw the oblation,

analyzed: śivam agnim ca sandhāya pūrṇām hutvā yathā uditām
translated: Having united Śiva and the fire, having offered the full oblation as prescribed,

original: anujñāpya śivaṃ paścānmaṇḍalād dakṣiṇe'mbuje /🔽kṛtanityavidhiṃ śiṣyaṃ svastikādyaiḥ suvarcite // //
analyzed: anujñāpya śivam paścāt maṇḍalāt dakṣiṇa imbuje  kṛta nitya vidhim śiṣyam svastika ādyaiḥ su varcite
translated: Having obtained permission from Śiva, on the lotus to the south of the maṇḍala,🔽The disciple who has performed the daily rites, well worshipped with the svastika and other seats,

analyzed: bhadra ananta āsane prāgvat sakalīkṛtya pūjayet                nirmathya gandha toyena prakṣālya abhyarcya dhūpitam
translated: Having made whole again as before, on the seat of Ananta, one should worship.🔽Having churned with the balls of white mustard, curd, clay, ash, dūrvā grass, cow dung,🔽Having washed with scented water, having worshipped, having fumigated,

analyzed: pṛthak mūla śata ālabdhaiḥ taiḥ kumbhaiḥ sva sva mantrataḥ
translated: Having consecrated with those pitchers obtained separately by the hundred roots, with their respective mantras,

analyzed: abhiṣicyāt tad vasanam ananta āsana gatam punar
translated: The disciple wearing a new garment, seated on the Ananta seat,

analyzed: sakalīkṛtya sampūjya dattvā uṣṇīṣa ādi sādhanam
translated: Having made whole again, having worshipped, having given the means of the uṣṇīṣa etc.,

analyzed: adhikāram ca vijñāpya śivāya asmai samarpayet
translated: Having informed of the authority, one should dedicate it to Śiva.

original: anujñāpya śivaṃ paścād gatvā kuṇḍāntikaṃ punaḥ // //
analyzed: anujñāpya śivam paścāt gatvā kuṇḍa antikam punar
translated: Having taken the disciple's permission, he should go near the sacrificial pit again.

analyzed: pañca pañca āhutīḥ ājyam kalānām ca juhoti atha
translated: Then he should offer five oblations of ghee for the five parts, and

original: pūrṇāṃ ca hutvā taddhastaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ parigṛhya tu // //
analyzed: pūrṇām ca hutvā tad hastam dakṣiṇam parigṛhya tu
translated: having offered the full oblation, he should take the right hand

analyzed: darbha ulmukena pañcāṅgaiḥ kaniṣṭhā ādiṣu lāñchayet
translated: and mark it with the five limbs using a darbha torch, starting from the little finger.

analyzed: prāgvat śivam tathā eva agnim kumbha astre ca visarjayet
translated: As before, he should bid farewell to Shiva, the fire, the water pot, and the weapon.

analyzed: hema vastra anna pāna ādyaiḥ paritoṣya atha tad janam
translated: Having satisfied the people with gold, clothes, food, drink, and so on,

analyzed: śiva guru ājñayā labdham adhikāram pravartayet
translated: he should perform the consecration obtained by the command of Shiva and the Guru.

analyzed: ittham dīkṣāḥ sa abhiṣekāḥ yathāvat prādhānyena atra uditāḥ tantra sidhāḥ
translated: Thus, the consecrations with ablution are properly mentioned here as the main ones, accomplished by the Tantras,

analyzed: yābhiḥ viśva kleśa hānim ca vindet bhoga aiśvaryāṇi api ayatnena mokṣam
translated: by which one attains the destruction of all afflictions, enjoyments, powers, and even liberation without effort.

original: iti śrīmadīśānaśivagurudevapaddhatau siddhāntasāre uparibhāge kriyāpāde sādhakadīkṣācāryābhiṣekapaṭala ekonaviṃśaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrīmat īśāna śiva guru deva paddhatau siddhāntasāre upari bhāge kriyā pāde sādhaka dīkṣā ācārya abhiṣeka paṭalaḥ ekonaviṃśaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the nineteenth chapter on the consecration of the aspirant and the preceptor in the Siddhāntasāra of the venerable Īśānaśivagurudeva's Paddhati, in the section on the rites of the lower part.

analyzed: atha viṃśaḥ paṭalaḥ
translated: Now, the twentieth chapter.

analyzed: atha pramāda skhalita vismṛti cyuta janmanām
translated: Now, for those whose birth has slipped away due to negligence, stumbling, or forgetfulness,

analyzed: doṣāṇām praśamāya atra prāyaścittam nigadyate
translated: For the removal of those faults, expiation is prescribed here.

analyzed: hastāt nipatite liṅge
translated: If the Linga falls from the hands or is touched by others who are not initiated,

analyzed: aghora ayuta jāpī syāt sa viśeṣa arcanāt śuciḥ
translated: One should perform ten thousand Japa of Aghora and become pure by special worship.

original: viśeṣārcanaśabdena pañcagavyapañcāmṛtasnapanamahānaivedyāgnikāryāntamarcayediti yāvat /🔽dvihastāt patite lakṣaṃ japet samprokṣaṇāt param /
analyzed: viśeṣa arcana śabdena pañcagavya pañcāmṛta snapana mahānaivedya agnikārya antam arcayet iti yāvat  dvi hastāt patite lakṣam japet samprokṣaṇāt param
translated: By the word special worship, it means one should worship up to the end of the ablution with the five products of the cow and the five nectars, the great offering, and the fire ritual.🔽If it falls from a height of two hands, one should perform one lakh Japa after the sprinkling (of the Linga).

analyzed: dvi tri lakṣa ādi jāpī syāt atas ca uccāt patet yadi
translated: If it falls from a higher height, one should perform two, three, or more lakhs of Japas.

original: bhinne liṅge'thavā pīṭhe prāyaścittaṃ na vidyate /
analyzed: bhinne liṅga ithavā pīṭhe prāyaścittam na vidyate
translated: If the Linga or the pedestal is broken, there is no expiation.

analyzed: tatas eva apramaḥ mādena rakṣaṇīyam prayatnataḥ
translated: Therefore, it should be carefully protected without any negligence.

analyzed: tathā viśīrṇa liṅga ādeḥ mahāpātaka śāntaye
translated: Similarly, for the purification of a greatly shattered Linga, etc.,

analyzed: prāyaścittam daśaguṇam kṛtvā kṛcchreṇa śudhyati  /
translated: One becomes pure by performing ten times the expiation and Krichchhra.

analyzed: a visarjite eva īśe sthaṇḍila ādau upadrute
translated: If the deity is obstructed in the Sthandila, etc., without being dismissed,

analyzed: aghora pañca sāhasram japet hutvā daśa aṃśataḥ
translated: One should perform five thousand Japas of Aghora and offer one-tenth of that in oblation.

analyzed: naṣṭe bhraṣṭe liṅge cora ādibhiḥ hṛte
translated: If the Linga is lost, burnt, fallen, or stolen by thieves, etc.,

original: lakṣaṃ japitvā samprokṣya labhyaṃ cet tad yajet punaḥ // //
analyzed: lakṣam japitvā samprokṣya labhyam ced tat yajet punar
translated: Having muttered a lakh and sprinkled it, if it is obtained, one should worship it again.

analyzed: tad alābhena aliṅgam vā pratiṣṭhāpya abhipūjayet
translated: If that is not obtained, one should install another linga and worship it.

original: sandhyālope tu nīrogaḥ sopavāsaḥ śataṃ japet // //
analyzed: sandhyā lope tu nīrogaḥ sa upavāsaḥ śatam japet
translated: In the omission of sandhya, being free from disease, one should fast and mutter a hundred times.

analyzed: pūjā upakaraṇe vā agnau pāda spṛṣṭe ca laṅghite
translated: In the case of the sacrificial vessel, fire, touching the feet, and transgressing,

analyzed: japet pañca sahasram tat śodhayet kṣālanena ca
translated: one should mutter five thousand times and purify it by washing.

analyzed: puṣpa ambu gandha mṛd pātra kṣīra anna ājyam parityajet
translated: One should abandon flowers, water, perfume, clay vessel, milk, food, and ghee.

analyzed: eka aham arcana lope tri rātra upoṣitaḥ japet
translated: In the omission of worship for one day, having fasted for three nights, one should mutter.

analyzed: sahasram dvi dina ādi arcā lope pi evam samūhayet
translated: In the omission of worship for two days and so on, one should collect in the same way.

original: pañcāhādadhikabhraṃśe kṛtvāsmādapi ṣaḍguṇam // //🔽sahasraṃ juhuyājjāpastatsaṃkhyo brahmaṇāṃ smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: pañca ahāt adhika bhraṃśe kṛtvā asmāt api ṣaḍguṇam  sahasram juhuyāt jāpaḥ tad saṃkhyaḥ brahmaṇām smṛtaḥ
translated: In the case of falling more than five days, having done even this, six times.🔽The reciter should offer one thousand oblations, and the number of Brahmas is remembered.

analyzed: akāmāt saṅkarāṇām tu brahmapañcaśatam japet
translated: For the unintentional mixing of castes, one should mutter five hundred Brahmas.

original: p / sopavāsaḥ śuciḥ pañcagavyaṃ prāśya juhoti ca /
analyzed: sa upavāsaḥ śuciḥ pañcagavyam prāśya juhoti ca
translated: Having fasted, being pure, having drunk the five products of the cow, one offers oblations.

analyzed: tatra  nirmālya saṅkare jāte pañca brahma śatam japet
translated: There🔽In the case of the mixture of offerings, one should mutter one hundred and five Brahmas.

analyzed: akāmāt bhakṣaṇe tasya sārdha sāhasrakam japet
translated: For the unintentional eating of it, one should mutter one thousand and five hundred.

analyzed: kāmāt ananta yāgena dīkṣayā ca padādhvanaḥ
translated: By the initiation with the endless offering, one should purify the path of words from desire.

analyzed: śudhyet atas tu nirmālyam na aśnīyāt na spṛśet api
translated: But one should not eat or even touch the remnants of worship.

original: anantayāgo nāma ananteśādividyeśvaraparivṛtasya śivasya pañcabrahmamaṇḍale'sminneva paṭale vakṣyamāṇo yāgo nirdiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: anantayāgaḥ nāma ananta īśa ādi vidyeśvara parivṛtasya śivasya pañca brahma maṇḍale ismin eva paṭale vakṣyamāṇaḥ yāgaḥ nirdiṣṭaḥ
translated: The endless offering is the sacrifice of Shiva, surrounded by the vidyadharas beginning with Ananta, which will be described in this very chapter on the mandala of the five Brahmas.

analyzed: nirmālya bhedāḥ kathyante ṣaḍvidhāḥ te api tat yathā
translated: The types of remnants of worship are described as being of six kinds. They are as follows:

original: devadravyaṃ ca devasvaṃ naivedyaṃ ca niveditam /
analyzed: deva dravyam ca deva svam naivedyam ca niveditam
translated: The property of the deity, the property of the gods, the offering made,

analyzed: caṇḍa dravyam ca nirmālyam teṣām lakṣaṇam ucyate
translated: and the remnants of worship of Chandika. Their characteristics are described.

original: vastrabhūṣaṇagandhādyaṃ devadravyamiti smṛtam /🔽devasvaṃ devasambandhi grāmakṣetrādi godhanam // //🔽devārthaṃ kalpitānnādyaṃ naivedyaṃ nāma tat punaḥ /
analyzed: vastra bhūṣaṇa gandha ādyam devadravyam iti smṛtam  deva svam deva sambandhi grāma kṣetra ādi go dhanam  deva artham kalpita annādyam naivedyam nāma tat punar
translated: The cloth, ornaments, fragrances, etc. are known as the property of the deity.🔽The property of the gods is the village, field, etc. related to the gods, and the wealth of cows.🔽The food, etc. set aside for the sake of the gods is known as the offering made.

analyzed: nivedita ākhyam utsṛṣṭam caṇḍa dravyam ca tat gatam
translated: What is discarded and called offered is the property of Chandika.

analyzed: garbhāgārāt bahis kṣiptam nirmālyam tat na saṃspṛśet
translated: The remnants of worship thrown outside the sanctum should not be touched.

analyzed: ṣaḍvidham ca api nirmālyam na upayuñjyāt kadācana
translated: And the six kinds of remnants of worship should never be used.🔽Here Bhoja Raja

analyzed: atra bhojarājaḥ
translated: says:

original: ṣaḍvidhamapi nirmālyaṃ na jighrenna laṅghayet nādyānna vikrīṇīyāt kravyādo bhavati bhuktvā mātaṅgo laṅghane'siddhirāghrāṇe vṛkaḥ sparśane strītvamatha caṇḍālo vikraye śavaraḥ iti /
analyzed: ṣaḍvidham api nirmālyam na jighret na laṅghayet na adyāt na vikrīṇīyāt kravya ādaḥ bhavati bhuktvā mātaṅgaḥ laṅghane siddhiḥ āghrāṇe vṛkaḥ sparśane strī tvam atha caṇḍālaḥ vikraye śavaraḥ iti
translated: One should not smell, not cross, not eat, and not sell the six kinds of Nirmalya. By eating it, one becomes a carnivorous animal. By crossing it, one becomes an elephant. By smelling it, one becomes a wolf. By touching it, one becomes a woman. By selling it, one becomes an outcaste.

analyzed: śiva nirmālya vat sauram caṇḍe dattam tatas adhikam
translated: Like the Nirmalya of Shiva, the offering made to the Sun is more powerful.

original: gurupustakavahniyakṣanāgayogīndragaṇamātṛgaurīṣu śivanirmālyavad na bhavati / acareṣvapi daśasthāneṣu guruvyākhyākāle śivakumbhe devapradakṣiṇe visarjite'pi deve liṅgasthā pūjā / calaliṅge aghaṭitaliṅge āsthāpyaliṅge citraratnaje hemaje anyasminnapi sadyaḥ pratiṣṭheti caturthīkarmāvadhi nirmālyaṃ na bhavatīti bhojarājaḥ /
analyzed: guru pustaka vahni yakṣa nāga yogi indra gaṇa mātṛ gaurīṣu śiva nirmālya vat na bhavati acareṣu api daśa sthāneṣu guru vyākhyā kāle śiva kumbhe deva pradakṣiṇe visarjite api deve liṅga sthā pūjā cala liṅge aghaṭita liṅge āsthāpya liṅge citraratna je hema je anyasmin api sadyas pratiṣṭhā iti caturthī karma avadhi nirmālyam na bhavati iti bhojarājaḥ
translated: In the case of the Guru, scriptures, fire, Yakshas, Nagas, Yogis, Indras, Mothers, Gauris, it is not like the Nirmalya of Shiva. Even in the case of immobile objects, in the ten places like the Guru's explanation, the Shiva Kalasha, circumambulation of the deity, even after the deity is dismissed, the worship performed on the Linga, in the case of a movable Linga, an unconstructed Linga, a consecrated Linga, one made of colorful gems, gold, or any other suddenly installed, the Nirmalya does not become impure, according to Bhoja Raja.

analyzed: pūjāyām gandha dhūpa ādeḥ avaśa āghrāṇa darśane   /
translated: In the worship, when there is an involuntary smelling of the fragrance of incense etc.,

analyzed: na asti doṣaḥ nadī vegāt āgata sparśana ādiṣu
translated: there is no fault in the case of contact etc. caused by the force of the river.

original: dīkṣitaḥ sūtake vātha śāvāśauce ca bhuktavān // //
analyzed: dīkṣitaḥ sūtake vā atha śāva āśauce ca bhuktavān
translated: The initiated person who has eaten during the period of impurity due to birth or death,

analyzed: na kāmataḥ sa upavāsaḥ vāmadeva sahasrakam
translated: If one has intentionally eaten without fasting, one should perform the Vamadeva Sahasraka.

original: japet kāmakṛte tasmāt triguṇaṃ śuddhaye smṛtam // //
analyzed: japet kāma kṛte tasmāt triguṇam śuddhaye smṛtam
translated: If it is done unintentionally, it is said that three times that is to be done for purification.

original: ātmasambandhike'śauce taṃ janaṃ na spṛśet svayam /
analyzed: ātma sambandhikā śauce tam janam na spṛśet svayam
translated: During one's own impurity, one should not touch that person oneself.

analyzed: pṛthak pākam upāśnīyāt snāna pūjā ādi karma ca
translated: One should eat separately cooked food, and perform the rites of bathing, worship, etc.

analyzed: nirvāṇa dīkṣitaḥ jñānī niśaṅkaḥ prāgvat ācāret
translated: One who is initiated for liberation and is wise should act as before without hesitation.

analyzed: nirbīja dīkṣayā ca api sāmayyā dīkṣitaḥ api vā
translated: Even one who is initiated with seedless initiation or one who is initiated in the Saṁvartā initiation

analyzed: svayam na saṃspṛśet liṅgam agnim ca anyena pūjayet
translated: should not touch the Liṅga or the fire himself, but worship through another.

analyzed: dīkṣitena eva śiṣyeṇa putra ādyaiḥ vā atha bandhubhiḥ
translated: Through the initiated disciple, or through the son or other relatives.

analyzed: nirvartya pūjā homa ādyam snātaḥ saṃyata vāc manāḥ
translated: Having performed the worship, oblation, etc., bathed, and controlled speech and mind,

analyzed: manasā eva uccaran mantrān sakalīkaraṇa ādikam
translated: uttering the mantras mentally, along with the Sakalīkaraṇa and other rites,

analyzed: kṛtvā puṣpa añjali kṣepaiḥ śivam tu kṛta maṇḍale
translated: having worshipped Śiva in the maṇḍala formed by the scattering of handfuls of flowers,

original: sampūjya manasā mantraṃ japitvāgniṃ praṇamya ca // //
analyzed: sampūjya manasā mantram japitvā agnim praṇamya ca
translated: having mentally worshipped the mantra, having muttered, having bowed to the fire,

analyzed: nayet
translated: eating separately cooked food, one should spend the day of impurity, etc.

original: samyag jñānī na duṣyet tu sūtāśaucaśatairapi // //
analyzed: samyak jñānī na duṣyet tu sūta āśauca śataiḥ api
translated: A truly wise person is not defiled even by hundreds of impurities and impurities.

original: tṛṇakāṣṭhacayacchanno yathā prajvālito'nalaḥ /🔽pramādāt sūtakāśauce bhuktvaikāhamupoṣitaḥ // //🔽japet sahasraṃ kāmena bhuktvā tattriguṇācchuciḥ /
analyzed: tṛṇa kāṣṭha caya channaḥ yathā prajvālita unalaḥ  pramādāt sūtaka āśauce bhuktvā eka aham upoṣitaḥ  japet sahasram kāmena bhuktvā tat triguṇāt śuciḥ
translated: Just as a fire covered with a heap of grass and wood burns,🔽having eaten by mistake during the impurity of a pregnant woman, one should fast for one day.🔽One should recite the mantra one thousand times out of desire. Having eaten, one becomes pure by three times that.

analyzed: bhuktvā tu sūtaka āśauce tad samaḥ hi aśuciḥ bhavet  /
translated: Having eaten during the impurity of a pregnant woman, one becomes impure equal to that.

original: taddinānte tu tāvanti dināni niśi yāvakam /
analyzed: tad dina ante tu tāvanti dināni niśi yāvakam
translated: At the end of that day, for as many nights as there are, one should eat barley.

analyzed: aśnan tri kāla snāyī syāt pratyaham tri śatam japet
translated: Bathing three times a day, one should recite three hundred times every day.

analyzed: pratiṣiddha anna bhuktau api ayam eva vidhiḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: This is the same procedure remembered for eating forbidden food.

original: retaḥ skanded yadi niśi sahasraṃ puruṣaṃ japet // //
analyzed: retaḥ skandet yadi niśi sahasram puruṣam japet  /
translated: If semen is emitted at night, one should recite the Purusha mantra one thousand times.

original: divase dviguṇaṃ tasmād dadyācca yavasaṃ gavām /
analyzed: divase dviguṇam tasmāt dadyāt ca yavasam gavām
translated: During the day, twice that of that, and one should give barley to cows.

analyzed: varṇānām brāhmaṇa ādīnām jāti īśāḥ puruṣa ādayaḥ
translated: The leaders of the castes beginning with Brahmins are the Purusha and others.

analyzed: atra svayam ucchiṣṭasya samāna jātīya ucchiṣṭa sparśe snātvā sva jāti īśvara śata japāt śuddhiḥ bhavet a dīkṣita ucchiṣṭa sparśe dviśatam japet svasmāt anantara varṇa ucchiṣṭa sparśe tu eka aham upoṣya sva jāti īśvaram spṛṣṭa varṇa īśvaram ca api ekīkṛtya śatam japet tatra eka antara varṇa ucchiṣṭa sparśe tu eka aham upoṣya sva jāti īśvaram spṛṣṭa varṇa īśvaram ca api ekīkṛtya śatam japet  /
translated: Here, if one who is himself impure touches another of the same caste who is impure, he should bathe and become pure by repeating the name of the Lord of his caste one hundred times. If he touches an initiated person who is impure, he should repeat the name two hundred times. If he touches an impure person of the next higher caste, he should fast for one day and repeat the name one hundred times, combining the names of the Lord of his own caste and the Lord of the caste of the person touched. If he touches an impure person of the next lower caste, he should fast for one day and repeat the name one hundred times, combining the names of the Lord of his own caste and the Lord of the caste of the person touched. If he touches an impure person of the next lower caste, he should fast for two days if the difference is one caste, for three days if the difference is two castes, and repeat the name as before. If he touches any of these uninitiated persons, he should do double the repetition. Similarly, if he touches an impure person of the next higher caste, he should do half the repetition and fast for one day, reducing by a quarter. If an impure person touches an outcaste, he should fast for three days, bathe, and repeat the name of the Lord of his caste ten thousand times.

translated: Here, if one who is not himself impure touches those who are impure as mentioned, he should perform a quarter of the mentioned penance. But if one who is himself impure touches those who are not impure, he should perform half of the penance. Or, having eaten the remnants of others, he should worship the Brahmanas in the Maṇḍala of the Five Brahmas and initiate them with the Jāti Uddhāra (Extraction of the Birth Caste). And that Maṇḍala should be made four cubits with four doors. Having installed Puruṣa and others in their respective directions in that (Maṇḍala), having worshipped the Lord of one's own caste, Īśāna, in the middle, having purified with the mantra of the Lord of one's own caste ending with Phaṭ, having extracted the caste, having thrown it into the Lord of one's own caste in the Maṇḍala with the mantra ending with Svāhā, having extracted and purified it, one should unite it with one's own self in the same way. Having thus extracted the caste, one should initiate with the Dīkṣā of one's own caste. If the Guru is not present, one should initiate oneself. If one is unable to initiate in this way, having fasted for six days, subsisting on wild food, one should recite the Lakṣa of the Lord of one's own caste,

translated: There, the performance of each of the Ekabhuka, Nakta-anna, Achyuta, and Upavasa separately and in order for three times, is the Krichchhra Dvada-sara-tra. And the Chandrayana is completed by one who, beginning with the first day of the bright fortnight, bathes three times a day, controls his senses, and eats fifteen morsels on the full moon day, increasing his morsels by one each day, starting with one morsel, and similarly, beginning with the first day of the dark fortnight, eats one morsel on the new moon day, decreasing his morsels by one each day, starting with fifteen morsels. This is the Yava-madhya Chandrayana. For the purification of all sins, whether mentioned or not, one should perform vows, fasts, Krichchhras, Chandrayanas, Japa, Homa, charity, pilgrimage, and austerities.

The difference between the ascendant of the sun at the time of entering the shadow and the ascendant of the sun,

translated: The time of the shadow's emergence and entry is the difference between the longitude of the sun and the ascendant, measured in solar ghatis. By multiplying that by the sine of the angle of the shadow at the time of entry or emergence, and dividing by the co-sine, one obtains the result in finger-breadths. With that result, one should move the sun's ayana by the number of finger-breadths obtained, reversing the ayana. This means that in the northern ayana one should move it to the south, and in the southern ayana to the north. The line thus moved touches the point on the horizon, and that is the east. Now, in order to know the directions by another method without the solar gnomon, it is said:

analyzed: chāyā traya agra udbhava vṛtta madhya spṛś sūtrayoḥ yatra yutiḥ pradeśe

When it is in the southern hemisphere, it is north of the base of the gnomon. Here again it is clearly stated. It is as follows: on a level ground, like water,

analyzed: prokta pramāṇam śaṅkum vinyasya pūrvāhṇe vā aparāhṇe chāyā agreṣu abhiniviṣṭeṣu triṣu trayaḥ bindavaḥ kāryāḥ tatas ekam bindum madhye kṛtvā iṣṭa pramāṇena vṛttam ālikhet tāvatā eva dvitīyam bindum avalambya dvitīyam vṛttam tadvat tṛtīyam bindum madhye kṛtvā tṛtīyam vṛttam ālikhet tatas tāvat pramāṇam eva vṛttam tathā ca ālikhet yathā madhya bindu vṛttam pārśva dvaya bindu vṛtta dvayasya khaṇḍam utpādayati tathā kṛte mat
translated: Having fixed the peg as described, in the forenoon or afternoon, when the shadows are fixed in the three directions, three drops should be made. Then, having made one drop in the middle, a circle should be drawn with the desired measure. Relying on the second drop just with that, the second circle should be drawn in the same way. Having made the third drop in the middle, the third circle should be drawn. Then, a circle of the same measure should be drawn in such a way that the middle circle produces a segment of the two circles at the two sides. When that is done, a pair of fish is produced. And of those two, the direction in which there is a large gap, those are the mouths. The direction in which there is proximity, those are the tails. Having placed two fine pegs in the mouths, having tied them with a thread, having drawn them out in the middle of the tails, one should lead them in their own direction. The point of intersection of those two threads according to the movement of the mouths and tails, that is the southern direction.

translated: The same cubit is called a ratni, if the little finger is extended.🔽The pradesha, tala, gokarna, and vitasti should be respectively🔽The distance from the tip of the thumb to the tip of the index finger, etc., up to the little finger, when extended,

original: p / yanmadhyamāmadhyamaparvadairghyānmānena mātrāṅgulamāyataṃ syāt /🔽tatparvamānena tadeva tiryaṅmātrāṅgulaṃ tacca tatābhidhānam // //
analyzed: yat madhyamā amadhyama parva dairghyāt mānena mātrā aṅgulam āyatam syāt  tad parva mānena tat eva tiryak mātra aṅgulam tat ca tata abhidhānam
translated: The length of the middle joint of the middle finger is the measure of the long finger.🔽The same, by the measure of its joint, is the broad finger, and that is called the broad finger.

analyzed: deha upalabdha aṅgulam iṣyate yat tat māna yuktyā pratimāsu vidyāt
translated: The finger that is obtained in the body should be known in the images by the measure of that.

original: daṇḍānāmaṣṭakaṃ rajjuḥ sā ca sīmādiṣu smṛtā /
analyzed: daṇḍānām aṣṭakam rajjuḥ sā ca sīmā ādiṣu smṛtā
translated: The set of eight daṇḍas and the rope are remembered in the case of boundaries etc.

analyzed: kiṣku hastena yāna ādi śayanīya ādi sādhanam
translated: The means of conveyance etc. and beds etc. are by the kiṣku-hand.

original: atrāha mayaḥ 🔽yāne ca śayane kiṣkuḥ prājāpatyaṃ vimānake /
analyzed: atra āha mayaḥ  yāne ca śayane kiṣkuḥ prājāpatyam vimānake
translated: Here Maya says:🔽The kiṣku is for conveyance and bed, the Prajāpati for the measuring of the house,

analyzed: vāstūnām tu dhanuḥ muṣṭiḥ grāma ādīnām dhanuḥ grahaḥ
translated: The bow-grip is for the villages etc.

analyzed: sarveṣām api vāstūnām kiṣkuḥ hastaḥ athavā bhavet
translated: For all the sites, the Kishku (cubit) or the Hasta (handspan) should be used.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: daṇḍena tu grāmaniveśanādyaṃ purāṇi kheṭaṃ nigamaṃ ca kuryāt /
analyzed: daṇḍena tu grāma niveśana ādyam purāṇi kheṭam nigamam ca kuryāt
translated: But the village, dwelling, etc., the cities, the market town, and the town should be made with the Danda (staff).

analyzed: hastena veśma ādiṣu mānam uktam svalpena ca eva aṅgulakaiḥ yavaiḥ vā
translated: The measurement in the house, etc., is said to be with the Hasta, and with a small number of Aṅgulas (finger-breadths) or Yavas (barley grains).

analyzed: devālaya gṛha ādīni kuryāt mātrā aṅgulena hi
translated: The temples, houses, etc., should be made with the Mātrā Aṅgula (measure).

analyzed: kuṇḍa ādikānām api maṇḍalānām sarvatra mātrā aṅgula mānataḥ syāt
translated: For the Maṇḍalas such as the Kuṇḍa (fire-pit), etc., everywhere the measurement should be with the Mātrā Aṅgula (measure).

analyzed: nirmāṇam iti atra yathāvat uktā tad tad kriyā bheda viśeṣa siddhiḥ
translated: The accomplishment of the various specific rites as stated is said to be the construction here.

original: iti śrīmadīśānaśivagurudevapaddhatau siddhāntasāre uparibhāge kriyāpāde śaṅkucchāyāṅgulādividhirnāma caturviṃśaḥ paṭalaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrīmat īśāna śiva guru deva paddhatau siddhāntasāre upari bhāge kriyā pāde śaṅkucchāyāṅgulādividhiḥ nāma caturviṃśaḥ paṭalaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the twenty-fourth chapter named The Method of Śaṅku, Chāyā, Aṅgula, etc. in the Siddhāntaśārīya Kriyāpāda of the venerable Iśānaśivagurudeva's Paddhati.

analyzed: atha pañcaviṃśaḥ paṭalaḥ
translated: Now, the twenty-fifth chapter.

analyzed: atha atas pada vinyāsaḥ kathyate vastu siddhaye
translated: Now, the arrangement of words is being told for the accomplishment of the object.

analyzed: sakalam pecakam pīṭham mahā pīṭha upapīṭhake
translated: The entire, the Peca, the Pīṭha, the Mahāpīṭha, the Upapīṭha,

analyzed: ugra pīṭham sthaṇḍilam ca maṇḍūkam paraśāyikam
translated: The Ugrapīṭha, the Sthaṇḍila, the Maṇḍūka, the Paraśāyika,

analyzed: āsanam ca iti daśadhā grāma ādi nyāsa caṇḍitam
translated: And the Āsana - these ten are praised for the arrangement of the village, etc.

analyzed: prānta sūtra catuṣka antar ekam syāt sakalam padam
translated: In the middle of the four corners of the thread, there should be one complete square.

analyzed: prācya udīcya eka sūtra ādi vṛddhyā tat syāt catuṣpadam
translated: By increasing the number of threads from east to north, it becomes a square of four squares.

analyzed: evam prāc uttara pada paṅkti vṛddhim kramāt nayet
translated: Thus, one should gradually increase the number of squares in the east and north.

original: catuṣpadaṃ pecakaṃ syāt pīṭhaṃ navapadaṃ smṛtam // //
analyzed: catuṣpadam pecakam syāt pīṭham nava padam smṛtam
translated: A square of four squares is called a pechika, and a square of nine squares is known as a seat.

analyzed: mahāpīṭham ṣoḍaśabhiḥ pañcaviṃśatibhiḥ padaiḥ
translated: A great seat is said to be sixteen squares, and a seat of twenty-five squares.

original: upapīṭhaṃ tu ṣaṭtriṃśatpadaiḥ syādugrapīṭhakam // //🔽sthaṇḍilaṃ hyūnapañcāśanmaṇḍūkaṃ cāṣṭakāṣṭakaiḥ /
analyzed: upapīṭham tu ṣaṭtriṃśat padaiḥ syāt ugrapīṭhakam  sthaṇḍilam hi ūnapañcāśat maṇḍūkam ca aṣṭaka aṣṭakaiḥ
translated: A subsidiary seat should be thirty-six squares, and an intense seat should be thirty-six squares.🔽A sacrificial ground is said to be less than fifty squares, and a sacrificial ground with eight sets of eight squares.

analyzed: ekāśīti padaiḥ khyātam kṣetram paramaśāyikam
translated: A sacrificial ground known as the supreme abode is said to be eighty-one squares.

original: āsanaṃ śatakoṣṭhaiḥ syād grāmādyaṃ tveṣuṃ siddhyati /
analyzed: āsanam śata koṣṭhaiḥ syāt grāma ādyam tu iṣum siddhi ati
translated: A seat should be one hundred squares, and a village, etc. are accomplished in these.

original: caturaśrāṣṭadaṇḍā bhūḥ kākaṇī taccaturguṇaḥ // //🔽māṣo vedaguṇaṃ tasmād bhaved vartanakāhvayam /
analyzed: caturaśra aṣṭa daṇḍā bhūḥ kākaṇī tad caturguṇaḥ
translated: The earth is four cubits in length and breadth, and a kākini is four times that.🔽A māṣa is said to be four times that, and a vartana is said to be four times that.

analyzed: tad pañca guṇitā vāṭī kuḍubam tad caturguṇam
translated: A vāṭī is five times that, and a kudumba is four times that.

analyzed: bhū mānam evam kathitam daṇḍa mānam tu kathyate
translated: Thus, the measure of land has been described. Now, the measure of a cubit is being described.

analyzed: mahā grāmasya uttamasya paryantaḥ lakṣa daṇḍavān
translated: The maximum extent of a great and excellent village is one lakh cubits.

analyzed: tasmāt viṃśati sāhasra daṇḍa hrāsāt krameṇa tu
translated: Therefore, from a reduction of twenty thousand dandas, gradually,

analyzed: grāmāṇām pañcadhā mānam mukhyam tu evam udīritam
translated: the main measure of villages is declared to be fivefold.

analyzed: daṇḍa viṃśati sāhasrāt daṇḍa pañcaśatasya tu
translated: From twenty thousand dandas to five hundred dandas,

analyzed: krama hrāsāt grāma mānā anyā pañca śata daṇḍataḥ
translated: the measures of villages decrease gradually, starting from five hundred dandas.

analyzed: catvāriṃśat prabhedāni madhyamāne bhavanti hi  grāma adhivāsa kṣetra ādeḥ sīmā mānam idam smṛtam
translated: There are forty subdivisions in the middle measure.🔽This is remembered as the measure of the boundaries of villages, settlements, fields, etc.

analyzed: prākāra anta ratha āvāsa sīmā mānam iha ucyate
translated: Now the measure of the boundaries of houses within the ramparts is stated.

analyzed: grāmaḥ ca kheṭakaḥ ca atha kharvaṭam durgam eva ca
translated: A village, a hamlet, then a small town, a fortress,

analyzed: nagaram rājadhānī ca pattanam droṇikāmukham
translated: a city, a capital, a town, a market place,

analyzed: śibiram skandhavāraḥ ca sthānīyam ca viḍambakam
translated: a camp, a caravan, a local place, a rural area,

analyzed: nigamaḥ ca atha nirdiṣṭaḥ syāt śākhānagaram tatas
translated: and a commercial town are then indicated.

analyzed: eṣām caturdaśānām ca lakṣaṇam pṛthak ucyate
translated: The characteristics of these fourteen are stated separately.

analyzed: aṣṭa aṣṭa daṇḍa vistāraḥ grāmaḥ syāt adhama adhamaḥ
translated: A village should be eight times eight dandas in extent, it is the lowest of the low.

analyzed: dviguṇa triguṇau tasmāt grāmau madhya uttamau smṛtau
translated: The middle and best villages are remembered to be twice and thrice that.

analyzed: ṣaṭpañcāśat ca dviśatam daṇḍāḥ kheṭedhame smṛtāḥ
translated: And fifty-six hundred and two hundred punishments are considered for the lowest fort.

analyzed: viṃśatyā tri śataiḥ daṇḍaiḥ madhyaḥ caturaśītibhiḥ
translated: And the middle one with twenty, three hundred and eighty-four punishments,

original: p / tribhiḥ śataiścottamaḥ syāt kheṭastvevaṃ tridhā smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: tribhiḥ śataiḥ ca uttamaḥ syāt kheṭaḥ tu evam tridhā smṛtaḥ
translated: and the best one with three hundred punishments - thus the fort is said to be of three types.

analyzed: aṣṭau ca catvāriṃśat ca daṇḍāḥ tadvat catuḥśatam
translated: And eight, forty and four hundred punishments are to be known in the lowest fort,

original: hīne tu kharvaṭe jñeyā madhye pañcaśatādhikam /
analyzed: hīne tu kharvaṭe jñeyā madhye pañca śata adhikam
translated: and five hundred more in the middle one,

analyzed: dvādaśa eva uttame ṣaḍbhiḥ saptatyā pañcabhiḥ śataiḥ
translated: and twelve, seventy-six and five hundred in the best one.

analyzed: hīna durgam ṣaṭśataiḥ ca catvāriṃśadbhiḥ anvitam
translated: The inferior fort should be known with six hundred and forty punishments,

analyzed: catur daṇḍa uttaraiḥ sapta śataiḥ durgam tu madhyamam  aṣṭaṣaṣṭi yutaiḥ sapta śataiḥ durgam iha uttamam
translated: the middle fort with seven hundred and fourteen punishments,🔽and the best fort here with seven hundred and sixty-six punishments.

analyzed: sa dvātriṃśat vasu śataiḥ ṣaṇṇavatyā aṣṭabhiḥ śataiḥ
translated: With thirty-two, eight hundred and ninety-six,

analyzed: ṣaṣ uttaraiḥ nava śataiḥ nīca tri nagarāṇi vai
translated: the inferior cities are with nine hundred and six,🔽and the inferior, middle and best cities are respectively with one thousand five hundred,

original: sahasreṇa ca sārdhena dvisahasreṇa ca kramāt // //🔽nīcaṃ madhyaṃ tathā śreṣṭhaṃ nagaraṃ madhyamatraye /
analyzed: sahasreṇa ca sārdhena dvi sahasreṇa ca kramāt  nīcam madhyam tathā śreṣṭham nagaram madhyama traye
translated: two thousand and three thousand.

analyzed: tri catuṣpañca sāhasraiḥ nagarāṇi uttama traye  /
translated: The inferior, middle and best cities are respectively with three, four and five thousand.

analyzed: ṣaṣ sapta aṣṭa sahasraiḥ tu daṇḍaiḥ syuḥ ca uttama uttame
translated: The best of the best cities should have six, seven, or eight thousand dandas.

analyzed: nagarāṇām traye tāni nagarāṇi yathākramam
translated: Those cities are in three groups of cities, in order.

analyzed: vikāra daṇḍa vṛddhyā tu pratyekam navadhā punar
translated: Again, each one is nine-fold due to the increase in the danda of modification.

analyzed: grāma ādīnām pramāṇāni proktāt ūrdhvam bhavanti hi
translated: The measurements of villages and others are said to be above that.

analyzed: rājadhānya ādikānām tu nagara vat bhavet
translated: But the measurements of the capital and others should be like the city.

analyzed: etāvat mānuṣeṣu eva mānam grāma ādiṣu smṛtam
translated: This is the measurement remembered for villages and others among humans.

analyzed: deva asura pura ādīnām mānam na jñāyate naraiḥ
translated: The measurements of the cities of gods and demons and others are not known by humans.

original: vistārāt pādamardhaṃ vā tripādadviguṇaṃ tu vā // //
analyzed: vistārāt pādam ardham vā tri pāda dviguṇam tu vā
translated: The width should be one-fourth, half, three-fourths, or double the length.

original: mukhāyāmo bhavedeṣāṃ grāmādinagarāntakam /🔽eteṣāṃ vipulāyāmāvayugmaireva daṇḍakaiḥ // //🔽vidhātavyāvataḥ śeṣaṃ vāṭīsañcārabhūmikā /

translated: This is the length and width of villages and others up to the city.🔽The remaining space should be made into gardens and walking grounds with even dandas of double the width of these.

analyzed: nadī ādeḥ dakṣiṇa ādye tu tīre grāmān niveśayet
translated: Villages should be located on the southern and other banks of rivers and others.

analyzed: grāmayoḥ antare kheṭam rāṣṭra madhye tu kharvaṭam
translated: A fortress should be built between two villages, and a fort should be built in the middle of the country.

original: parvatāntarvane vābdhau durgaṃ syād vā jalāvṛtam // //
analyzed: parvata antar vane vā abdhau durgam syāt vā jala āvṛtam
translated: A fortress should be surrounded by a mountain, forest, or ocean, or be surrounded by water.

original: p / durgaṃ tu pārvataṃ vanyamaudakaṃ cairiṇaṃ tathā /
analyzed: durgam tu pārvatam vanyam audakam cairiṇam tathā
translated: A fortress is difficult to conquer if it is mountainous, forested, watery, arid, or has a natural barrier.

original: daivikaṃ dhānvanaṃ caiva kṛtakaṃ ceti saptadhā // //
analyzed: daivikam dhānvanam ca eva kṛtakam ca iti saptadhā
translated: A fortress is of seven kinds: mountainous, forest, watery, desert, divine, wild, and artificial.

original: rāṣṭrasya madhye nadyā vā samīpe nagaraṃ smṛtam /
analyzed: rāṣṭrasya madhye nadyāḥ vā samīpe nagaram smṛtam
translated: The fortress in the middle of the country or near a river is considered a city.

analyzed: tat eva śaṅku paṅka ādyaiḥ parikhābhiḥ durāsadam  ucca prākāraka aṭṭāla gopura kṣepaṇī hulaiḥ
translated: That itself, difficult to approach due to moats with thorns, mud, etc.,🔽With high walls, towers, gates, catapults, and javelins,

analyzed: śataghnībhiḥ ca paritas paristīrṇa ucchrita aṭṭakam
translated: Surrounded by high towers on all sides,

analyzed: eka dvi tri catur dvāram rājadhānī iti kathyate
translated: With one, two, three, or four gates, is called a royal palace.

analyzed: nānā paṇya dhana ākīrṇam sāgara anūpa saṃśritam  sāṃyānika vaṇij juṣṭam pattanam paricakṣate
translated: Filled with various merchandise and wealth, situated on the shore of the ocean,🔽Crowded with traders and merchants, is called a port.

analyzed: tat eva abdheḥ ca nadyāḥ ca saṅgama āgata potakam
translated: That itself, with boats coming from the confluence of the ocean and river,

analyzed: dvīpa antara vaṇij juṣṭam viduḥ droṇa mukham budhāḥ
translated: Crowded with traders from other islands, the wise know as a harbor.

analyzed: para rāṣṭre sva deśe vā caturvidha bala anvitam
translated: In an enemy's country or one's own country, endowed with four kinds of forces,

analyzed: vijigīṣoḥ sanniveśam śibiram tat pracakṣate
translated: The wise call the encampment of a conqueror a camp.

analyzed: na ati dūre tat eva syāt nṛpayoḥ yudhyatoḥ mithas
translated: That should not be too far away, when two kings fight each other,

analyzed: senāniveśaḥ tu pṛthak skandhāvāraḥ iti smṛtaḥ
translated: The separate encampment of the army is known as the Skandhavāra (military camp).

analyzed: parvatasya athavā nadyāḥ pārśve rāja bala anvitam
translated: On the side of a mountain or river, along with the king's forces,

original: rāṣṭrānte sāntapālaṃ yat tat sthānīyaṃ vidurbudhāḥ /
analyzed: rāṣṭra ante sa antapālam yat tat sthānīyam viduḥ budhāḥ
translated: The wise know that which is protected by the king at the border of the kingdom as Sthānīya (local).

analyzed: kṛṣīvala ādika āvāsaḥ grāma upānte viḍambakam  cāturvarṇaiḥ karmakāraiḥ nānā karma upajīvibhiḥ
translated: The residence of farmers and others at the edge of the village is known as Viḍambaka.

analyzed: paṇyaiḥ ca dhana dhānya ādyaiḥ yuktaḥ tu nigamaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: A town is said to be endowed with people of the four castes engaged in various occupations, and with goods, wealth, grains, etc.

original: vane vā nagaropānte nāgaraistu janairvṛtam /🔽kṣetrārāmākaropetaṃ śākhānagaramiṣyate // //🔽sahasrairjagatīpaṅtivasusaṃkhyairdvijanmanām /
analyzed: vane vā nagara upānte nāgaraiḥ tu janaiḥ vṛtam  kṣetra ārāma ākara upetam śākhānagaram iṣyate  sahasraiḥ jagatī paṅti vasu saṃkhyaiḥ dvijanmanām
translated: In the forest or near the city, surrounded by urban people,🔽Possessing fields, gardens, and mines, it is considered a branch city.

analyzed: śreṣṭha uttamaḥ śreṣṭha madhyaḥ grāmaḥ śreṣṭha adhamaḥ tathā
translated: A village is considered best, excellent, middling, and inferior based on the number of brahmins ranging from one thousand to three thousand.

analyzed: sapta ṣaṣ pañca sāhasraiḥ grāmāḥ madhya uttama ādayaḥ
translated: The middling villages are of three types, excellent, middling, and inferior, with seven, six, and five thousand brahmins respectively.

original: catustridvisahasraistu grāmāḥ syuradhame trayaḥ // //🔽p / viprāṇāṃ daśasapteṣuśatairnīcottamādayaḥ /
analyzed: catur tri dvi sahasraiḥ tu grāmāḥ syuḥ adhame trayaḥ   viprāṇām daśa sapta iṣu śataiḥ nīca uttama ādayaḥ
translated: The three inferior villages have four, three, and two thousand brahmins respectively.🔽The inferior, excellent, and middling villages have eleven, ten, and nine hundred brahmins respectively.

analyzed: grāmāḥ bhavanti atha kṣudrāḥ te api ekādaśadhā smṛtāḥ
translated: The small villages are also said to be of eleven types.

analyzed: catur tri dvi śataiḥ aṣṭaśataiḥ caturaśītikaiḥ  sa catuḥṣaṣṭi pañcāśat dvātriṃśat tri aṣṭakaiḥ api  vikāra āditya saṃkhyaiḥ ca brāhmaṇaiḥ tu niveśitaiḥ  eka dvija ādyāḥ daśa antāḥ tu eka bhoga ādikāḥ daśa
translated: With four, three, two, one hundred and eighty, eighty-four, eighty,🔽With sixty-four, fifty, thirty-two, twenty-eight,🔽And with the number of modifications, beginning with the sun, established by the Brahmanas,🔽From one Brahmin up to ten, and from one enjoyment up to ten.

analyzed: prāc pratyak āyatāḥ tisraḥ saumyāḥ tisraḥ utha vīthayaḥ

analyzed: catasraḥ pañca vā ṣaḍ vā sapta vā prastare smṛtā

analyzed: catasraḥ vīthayaḥ prācyāḥ saumyāḥ dvādaśa vīthayaḥ

analyzed: rudra diś nanda vasubhiḥ mitāḥ syuḥ vā prakīrṇake  /
translated: measured by Rudra, directions, Nandins and Vasus, should be in the Prakirnaka.

original: p / prāk pratyagvīthayaḥ pañca saumyāśca syustrayodaśa /
analyzed: prāk pratyak vīthayaḥ pañca saumyāḥ ca syuḥ trayodaśa
translated: In the east and west there are five streets, and in the north there should be thirteen.

analyzed: śakvaryā ca atiśakvaryā ca aṣṭyā atyaṣṭyā ca sammitāḥ
translated: They are equal to the Shakvari, Ati-shakvari, Ashta and Ati-ashta meters.

original: nandyāvarte tu vinyāse grāmādeḥ prabhavanti hi /
analyzed: nandyāvarte tu vinyāse grāma ādeḥ prabhavanti hi
translated: In the arrangement of the Nandya-vartta, the prosperity of the village etc. indeed arises.

analyzed: prācyāḥ ṣaḍ vīthayaḥ yasmin saumyāḥ dhṛti ādi saṃkhyayā

analyzed: ākṛti antam samāḥ yatra parāgaḥ saḥ abhidhīyate

analyzed: prācīnāḥ vīthayaḥ sapta trayoviṃśa āditaḥ kramāt
translated: The seven paths in the east are from Trayoviṃśa in order.

original: oṃ saptaviṃśateḥ saumyā vinyāse padmake smṛtāḥ /🔽prācīnā vīthayo'ṣṭau syuraṣṭaviṃśatimāditaḥ // //
analyzed: om saptaviṃśateḥ saumyāḥ vinyāse padmake smṛtāḥ  prācīnāḥ vīthayā uṣṭau syuḥ aṣṭaviṃśatimāditaḥ

analyzed: ādvātriṃśam udīcyāḥ syuḥ vinyāse śrī pratiṣṭhite

analyzed: mahendre gṛharakṣe ca bhallāṭe puṣpadantake  /

analyzed: mahādvārāṇi ca eva syuḥ upadvārāṇi santi ced
translated: If there are secondary doors,

analyzed: bhṛśe pūṣaṇi bhṛṅga ākhye dauvāre śoṣa nāgayoḥ  /
translated: in Bhṛśa, Pūṣan, Bhṛṅga, the two doors of Dvau and Nāga,

analyzed: ca parjanye jala mārgāḥ tu atha aindrataḥ
translated: and also in Parjanya, the rain-god, the water-paths are from Indra.

analyzed: īśa argala antam śastāḥ syuḥ prāc udīcī plavaḥ yathā
translated: Up to the door-bolt of Īśa, they should be recommended, like a raft in the northeast.

original: sūrye sūryo bhṛśe viṣṇuragnau kālī yame guhaḥ /
analyzed: sūrye sūryaḥ bhṛśe viṣṇuḥ agnau kālī yame guhaḥ

analyzed: viṣṇoḥ madhye ca varuṇe sugrīve sugata ālayaḥ
translated: in the middle of Viṣṇu, in Varuṇa, in Sugrīva, the abode of the Sugatas.

original: bhṛṅge jinasya jyeṣṭhāyā vāyau cāṇḍyāstu mukhyake /
analyzed: bhṛṅge jinasya jyeṣṭhāyāḥ vāyau cāṇḍyāḥ tu mukhyake

analyzed: kuberasya mahākālyāḥ mātṝṇām ca niśākare
translated: Kubera, Mahākālī, the Mothers, and the Moon,

analyzed: aditau vāstucāmuṇḍyāḥ śaste aiśe śiva ālayaḥ
translated: In the northeast, the abode of Caṇḍikā, and in the northeast, the temple of Śiva.

original: nirṛtau vā jayante vā vighneśasya gṛhaṃ bhavet // //
analyzed: nirṛtau vā jayante vā vighneśasya gṛham bhavet  /
translated: In the southwest or southeast, the house of Gaṇeśa should be.

analyzed: athavā devatānām tu vinyāsam apare jaguḥ
translated: Or others have declared the arrangement of the deities to be different.

analyzed: tat grāma pura rāṣṭrāṇām syāt madhye brāhmaṇaḥ gṛham  /
translated: In the middle of villages, towns, and kingdoms, the house of a Brāhmaṇa should be.

original: prācyāṃ vā paścime viṣṇorgrāmādīnāṃ ca sammukham /
analyzed: prācyām vā paścime viṣṇoḥ grāma ādīnām ca sammukham

analyzed: parāṅmukham syāt aiśānyām mānuṣam śiva mandiram
translated: The temple of Śiva should be in the northeast, facing away.

original: svayambhudaivikaṃ cārṣaṃ yatra tatra sthitaṃ tu vā /
analyzed: svayambhu daivikam ca ārṣam yatra tatra sthitam tu vā
translated: Whether it is self-existent, divine, or Ārṣa, located anywhere,

analyzed: na doṣāya bhavet tasya api agram varjyam śubha arthibhiḥ  madhye gauryāḥ sūryasya ca śriyaḥ
translated: It will not cause harm. The front part of it should be avoided by those seeking auspiciousness.🔽In the east, northeast, or middle, the temple of Gaurī, the Sun, and Śrī,

analyzed: mātṝṇām dakṣiṇe dhāma śāstuḥ kālyāḥ ca nairṛte  /

analyzed: ṣaṇmukhasya tu vāruṇyām jyeṣṭhāyāḥ tad anantaram
translated: In the southwest of Ṣaṇmukha, and after that, of Jyeṣṭhā,

analyzed: vāyau saumye ca durgāyāḥ lokeśānām sva gocare  /
translated: In the northwest and northeast, of Durgā, and of the Lokapālas in their own quarters.

analyzed: indra īśa soma madhye vā kṣetrapāla niketanam
translated: Between Indra, Īśa, and Soma, or in the middle, the abode of Kṣetrapāla,

analyzed: deśa grāma pura ādīnām evam ṛddhi karam bhavet
translated: This will bring prosperity to the country, villages, cities, and so on.

original: gośālā dakṣiṇe prācyā vāpī tvaiśe tathottare /
analyzed: go śālā dakṣiṇe prācyā vāpī tu aiśe tathā uttare

analyzed: dakṣiṇe gaṇikā vāṭaḥ paritas śūdra janmanām
translated: A brothel in the south, and around it, the houses of Shudra-born people,

analyzed: vaiśyānām vaṇijām prācyām madhye rājāpaṇaḥ bhavet  prāc udīcyoḥ kulālānām nāpitānām ca tatra hi  jālikānām ca vāyavye sūnānām paścime gṛham
translated: The houses of Vaishyas and traders in the east, and the royal market in the middle.🔽Potters and barbers there in the northeast,🔽The houses of butchers in the northwest and those of oil-sellers in the north,

original: tailavikrayiṇāṃ saumye takṣṇāṃ vāpyanile'nale /🔽vāyavye kārukādīnāṃ kuvindānāṃ tu paścime // //🔽krośadvaye vā krośe vā bahiścaṇḍālapakkaṇam /

translated: The houses of carpenters in the northwest and those of accountants in the west.🔽The settlement of Chandalas should be two or three miles outside,

analyzed: prāguttareṇa tu krośāt bahis pitṛvanam bhavet  /
translated: And the cremation ground should be a mile or more to the north-east.

analyzed: anuktānām tathā anyeṣām yuktyā vāsam prakalpayet
translated: The houses of other unspecified people should be located by reasoning.

analyzed: rājadhānyām nṛpa āvāsaḥ brahma aṃśāt apara aṃśake  /
translated: The king's residence should be in the royal capital, in the part of the city belonging to Brahma.

analyzed: tasya prācyām tu bāhya āliḥ indrakośa sabhā anvitaḥ
translated: Outside that, in the east, is the outer wall, along with Indra's treasury and assembly hall.

original: pākaśālāntarikṣe'gnau śayanaṃ gṛharakṣake // //🔽astraśālā ca nirṛtau varuṇe bhojanālayaḥ /
analyzed: pākaśālā antarikṣa ignau śayanam gṛharakṣake  astra śālā ca nirṛtau varuṇe bhojana ālayaḥ
translated: The kitchen should be in the sky, the sleeping quarters in the house protector,🔽The weapons room in Nirriti, the dining hall in Varuna,

analyzed: vihāra śālā vāyau syāt bhallāṭe kośa sañcayaḥ  /
translated: The recreation hall should be in Vayu, the treasury in Bhallata,

original: koṣṭhāgāraṃ tathā saumye vyāyāmo'pyargale smṛtaḥ /🔽parjanye snānabhavanamaiśe homārcanāgṛhe // //
analyzed: koṣṭhāgāram tathā saumye vyāyāmaḥ upi argale smṛtaḥ  parjanye snāna bhavanam aiśe homa arcanā gṛhe
translated: The granary in Soma, and exercise is remembered in Argala,🔽The bathing house in Parjanya, and the fire and worship room in Isha,

original: nṛttaśālā tu gāndharve gajaśālā tu pūṣaṇi /
analyzed: nṛtta śālā tu gāndharve gaja śālā tu pūṣaṇi
translated: The dance hall in Gandharva, the elephant stable in Pushan,

analyzed: diti adityoḥ turaṅgāṇām strīṇām saumye ca paścime
translated: The horses of Diti and Diti in the west of Soma,

original: p / madhye prapāṃ maṇḍapaṃ vā yuktyānyaccāpi kārayet /
analyzed: madhye prapām maṇḍapam vā yuktyā anyat ca api kārayet
translated: In the middle, one should make a well or a pavilion, and other things as appropriate.

analyzed: brāhmaṇa kṣatriya viśām śūdrāṇām dhaninām api
translated: For Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, Shudras, and wealthy people,

analyzed: vakṣyamāṇāḥ tu ye jāti prāsādāḥ sampadām padam
translated: The caste palaces mentioned below are the abode of prosperity.

analyzed: aśaktānām tu śālāḥ syuḥ tad tad yuktyā vinirmitāḥ
translated: But for those who are unable, the halls should be constructed according to their means.

analyzed: ittham grāma pura ādi mānam akhilam proktam tathā lakṣaṇam
translated: Thus, all the measurements of villages, cities, etc. have been described, as well as their characteristics,

analyzed: brahma agastya purandaraiḥ api yathā tvaṣṭrā mayena uditam
translated: As told by Brahma, Agastya, Indra, Vishvakarma, Maya, and others,

analyzed: yat vijñāya niveśiteṣu vidhinā dhāmasu aśeṣa amaraiḥ
translated: By knowing which, the remaining gods have been duly installed in their abodes,

analyzed: sampūjyaḥ munibhiḥ tathā eva manujaiḥ devaḥ mṛḍānī patiḥ
translated: And worshipped by the sages and men, the god, the lord of Mṛḍānī.

original: iti śrīmadīśānaśivagurudevapaddhatau siddhāntasāre uparibhāge kriyāpāde padavinyāsagrāmapuralakṣaṇaṃ nāma pañviṃśaḥ paṭalaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrīmat īśāna śiva guru deva paddhatau siddhāntasāre upari bhāge kriyā pāde padavinyāsagrāmapuralakṣaṇam nāma pañviṃśaḥ paṭalaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the twenty-fifth chapter named the characteristics of the village and town in the arrangement of words in the section on rites in the Siddhāntaśārā of the Paddhati of the venerable Īśānaśivagurudeva.

analyzed: atha ṣaḍviṃśaḥ paṭalaḥ
translated: Now, the twenty-sixth chapter.

analyzed: atha liṅga pratiṣṭhāyai prāsāda karaṇam prati
translated: Now, for the installation of the Liṅga, regarding the construction of the temple,

analyzed: karṣaṇa ādi kriyā cakram jñeyam tat likhyate adhunā
translated: The circle of activities beginning with plowing should be known. That is being written now.

analyzed: guṇavat deśa kāla āptiḥ avekṣya asmin viśeṣataḥ
translated: The acquisition of a good place and time should be especially considered in this.

original: sukṣetre codite kāle bījamuptaṃ hi rohati // //🔽jalasekādibhiḥ kṛtyairabhīṣṭaphaladaṃ ca tat /
analyzed: su kṣetre ca udite kāle bījam uptam hi rohati  jala seka ādibhiḥ kṛtyaiḥ abhīṣṭa phala dam ca tat
translated: For, a seed sown in an indicated field at the right time does grow.🔽And it yields the desired fruit by such acts as watering.

analyzed: karṣaṇa ādi kriyā siddhe prāsāde lakṣaṇa anvite
translated: In a temple endowed with auspicious characteristics, accomplished by the acts of plowing etc.,

analyzed: viśiṣṭa deśe kāle ca vidhinā eva pratiṣṭhite
translated: Installed by the rules alone in an excellent place and time,

original: liṅge karoti sānnidhyaṃ śivaḥ kartuśca bhūtaye // //
analyzed: liṅge karoti sānnidhyam śivaḥ kartuḥ ca bhūtaye
translated: Śiva manifests himself in the Liṅga for the welfare of the doer.

analyzed: atra uttarayaṇaḥ kālaḥ niyataḥ karṣaṇa ādike
translated: Here, the time of Uttarāyaṇa is fixed for plowing etc.

analyzed: māsāḥ ca anadhikāḥ pakṣaḥ śuklaḥ tu tithayaḥ śubhāḥ
translated: And the months should not be in excess, the fortnight should be bright, and the lunar days auspicious.

analyzed: parva rikta aṣṭamī viṣṭi pratipad varjitāḥ tu yāḥ
translated: Those days which are free from Parva (lunar days), Ashtami (8th lunar day), Vrishi (lunar mansion), Pratipada (1st lunar day),

original: karaṇāni vinā viṣṭiṃ śakuniṃ ca catuṣpadam // //
analyzed: karaṇāni vinā viṣṭim śakunim ca catuṣpadam
translated: Except Vrishi, Shakunis (auspicious moments), and quadrupeds,

original: nāgakiṃstughnakau hitvā śastāni sukhadāni ca /🔽candrajñaguruśukrāṇāṃ vāradrekkāṇakāṃśakāḥ // //
analyzed: nāga kiṃstughnakau hitvā śastāni sukha dāni ca
translated: Leaving aside Naga, Kinstughna, and other auspicious and comfortable Karana (division of the day),🔽The Drekkanas and Amsas of the Moon, Jupiter, Guru, and Shukra,

analyzed: śastāḥ guru jña kāvyānām horāḥ ca udaya dṛṣṭayaḥ
translated: The Hora of Guru and Jna are auspicious, as well as the Udaya and Drishtas.

analyzed: pāpānām aṃśa divasa drekkāṇa udaya dṛṣṭayaḥ
translated: The Amsas, days, Drekkanas, Udayas, and Drishtas of the malefic planets,

analyzed: horāḥ ca aśobhanāḥ sarve grahāḥ tvostvāya gatāḥ śubhāḥ
translated: And all the inauspicious Horas, the planets have gone to the Udas, the auspicious ones,

analyzed: tri ṣaṣṭha āya gatāḥ pāpāḥ śastāḥ na iṣṭāḥ tatonyatas
translated: The malefics in the 3rd, 6th, and 11th houses are auspicious, not desired in other places.

analyzed: ṣaṣ saptadaśa gaḥ śukraḥ na iṣṭaḥ anyatra śubha āvahaḥ
translated: Shukra in the 6th, 7th, or 15th house is not desired, auspicious elsewhere.

analyzed: sarve api aṣṭama gāḥ na iṣṭāḥ śukraḥ tatra api śobhanaḥ
translated: All in the 8th house are not desired, but Shukra there is also auspicious.

analyzed: dvitīya pañca gaḥ candraḥ jñaḥ sapta nava pañca gaḥ
translated: The Moon in the 2nd or 5th house, Jna in the 7th, 9th, or 5th house,

analyzed: dvi sapta pañca navame guruḥ ca ete śubha āvahāḥ  saumya āditya aśvi tiṣyāṇi hasta pauṣṇe tris uttarāḥ
